title: Wall Drawing #63: A wall is divided into four horizontal parts. In the top row are four equal vertical divisions, each with lines in a different direction. In the second row, six double combinations; in the third row, four triple combinations; in the bottom row, all four combinations superimposed.

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of black pencil.

description: Over nearly four decades, Sol LeWitt’s work—equal parts conceptual and visual—introduced new ways of making and thinking about art. The artist posited his influential ideas most clearly in over 1,200 wall drawings, conceived in the form of written instructions and a diagram. LeWitt shared the creation of his work with other makers: this piece was drawn by Roland Lusk, Eileen Jeng, and Jason Stec (January–February 2009) and varnished by John Hogan.
credit_line: Gift of Stefan T. Edlis and Gael Neeson
publication_history:
Alicia Legg, ed., Sol LeWitt, with essays by Lucy R. Lippard, Bernice Rose, and Robert Rosenblum, exh. cat. (New York: Museum of Modern Art, 1978), 86, cat. 150 (represented by Composite: Lines in Four Directions in Single, Double, Triple, and Quadruple Combinations, 1969, pen-and-ink drawing).

Danielle Rice and Andrea Miller-Keller, Sol LeWitt Wall Drawings: 1968–1981, exh. brochure (Hartford: Wadsworth Atheneum, 1981), n.p. (by error as 1969).

Sol LeWitt and Susanna Singer, Sol LeWitt: Wall Drawings, 1968–1984 (Amsterdam: Stedelijk Museum, 1984), 44; 45, cat. 63 (represented by pen-and-ink drawing); 166.

Sol LeWitt and Lorena Martínez de Corral, Sol LeWitt: Dibujos Murales/Wall Drawings, exh. cat. (Madrid: Caja de Madrid, 1996), 75, 126.

Gary Garrels, ed., Sol LeWitt: A Retrospective, with essays by Martin Friedman, Andrea Miller-Keller, Brenda Richardson, Anne Rorimer, John S. Weber, and Adam D. Weinberg, exh. cat. (San Francisco: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art; New Haven: Yale University Press, 2000), 158, cat. 78 (represented by Composite Series [set of five], 1971, silkscreen); 404.
exhibition_history:
Geneva, Switzerland, Phillipe-Guy Woog residence, Jan. 1971, drawn by Kazuko Miyamoto, no cat.

New York, Museum of Modern Art, Sol LeWitt, Feb. 3–Apr. 4, 1978, cat. 150 (represented by Composite: Lines in Four Directions in Single, Double, Triple, and Quadruple Combinations, 1969, pen-and-ink drawing); Montreal, Musee d'Art Contemporain, Sept. 7–Oct. 22, 1978; Champaign, IL, Krannert Art Museum, University of Illinois, Mar. 4–Apr. 8, 1979; Chicago, Museum of Contemporary Art, June 8–Aug. 12, 1979; La Jolla, CA, Museum of Contemporary Art, Sept. 16–Nov. 4, 1979. 

Hartford, CT, Wadsworth Atheneum, Sol LeWitt Wall Drawings: 1968–1981, Sept. 29–Nov. 22, 1981, brochure, no cat. no.

Madrid, La Sala de las Alhajas, Sol LeWitt: Dibujos Murales/Wall Drawings, Feb. 6–Mar. 30, 1996, no cat. no. 

Art Institute Chicago, Apr. 1997, drawn by Devorah Heitner, Anthony Sansotta, and Russell Williams, varnished by John Hogan, no cat.

San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Sol LeWitt: A Retrospective, Feb. 19–May 30, 2000, cat. 78 (represented by Composite Series [set of five], 1971, silkscreen); Chicago, Museum of Contemporary Art, July 22–Oct. 22, 2000; New York, Whitney Museum of American Art, Dec. 7, 2000–Feb. 25, 2001. 

Art Institute of Chicago, Feb. 2009, drawn by Roland Lusk, Eileen Jeng, and Jason Stec, varnished by John Hogan, no cat.

Art Institute of Chicago, October 2015-to present, ddrawn by Roland Lusk, Kittisak Chontong, and Gwendolyn Zabicki, no cat.
provenance_text: The artist; sold through the John Weber Gallery, New York to Phillipe-Guy Woog, Geneva, Switzerland, Dec. 1971. Robert Feldman, New York, sold to Young/Hoffman Gallery, Chicago; sold to Stefan T. Edlis and Gael Neeson, Chicago, Mar. 1983; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, Dec. 30, 1985.

input: Wall Drawing #63: A wall is divided into four horizontal parts. In the top row are four equal vertical divisions, each with lines in a different direction. In the second row, six double combinations; in the third row, four triple combinations; in the bottom row, all four combinations superimposed.
